text: It's not the fees that matter, its the amount you actually receive in the Philippines because of the exchange rates that banks and transfer companies offer.  Western union offers the worst exchange rate  of all banks and remittance companies thereby ripping you off with hidden fees. A comparison video on YouTube called   How to transfer Dollars to the Philippines in Peso or dollar account   posted by Vlogger Grandpa, USA   makes it plain which companies are the best .    From NZ to Philippines  TransferWise  offers the true mid market exchange rates  and very low up front fees  and is much cheaper than Western Union

author: A Mighty Life

text: Yeah, PayPal and Xoom's exchange rate are pretty bad. Sometimes, Remitly's is too. So, it's best to compare different services. Remitly usually charges a fee for express transfers. But if you use a US bank account, there is no fee. But you need to wait for 3-4 business days for the transaction to be completed.    I'm not sure about the experience of those who say that it took 10 days but in my experience, Express (pay via debit card) service takes minutes to send to my Philippine bank account. If I use a bank account payment option, it takes about 4 business days.    For PayPal, the recipient also needs to have a PayPal account, sending to friends and family is free, although they may charge some other fees, not sure. It's been a while since I used this service. Your recipient will then need to have a bank account connected to PayPal and from what I understand, there is also a fee for transferring money from PayPal to bank account.
author: A Mighty Life

text: Thanks! My top three are: Remitly, Xoom, & Transferwise. But I still compare sometimes because the exchange rate varies. Xoom waives the fees for transfers $200 & up.
author: A Mighty Life

text: Yeah, there are a lot of negative comments. But there are also those who say that the app works for them. At the end of the day, we make comparisons and choose what works for ourselves. In my case, Remitly, Xoom, and Transferwise are my top 3. Although, I still compare exchange rates and fees among the three because it can still vary.       For USD (from the US) to a USD account in the Philippines, I have used Xoom.com in the past and had been satisfied although I feel that the fee is still a bit high. I hope you find what works for you.
author: A Mighty Life

text: Yeah, PayPal and Xoom's exchange rate are pretty bad. Sometimes, Remitly's is too. So, it's best to compare different services. Remitly usually charges a fee for express transfers. But if you use a US bank account, there is no fee. But you need to wait for 3-4 business days for the transaction to be completed.    I'm not sure about the experience of those who say that it took 10 days but in my experience, Express (pay via debit card) service takes minutes to send to my Philippine bank account. If I use a bank account payment option, it takes about 4 business days.    For PayPal, the recipient also needs to have a PayPal account, sending to friends and family is free, although they may charge some other fees, not sure. It's been a while since I used this service. Your recipient will then need to have a bank account connected to PayPal and from what I understand, there is also a fee for transferring money from PayPal to bank account.
author: A Mighty Life

text: Thanks! My top three are: Remitly, Xoom, & Transferwise. But I still compare sometimes because the exchange rate varies. Xoom waives the fees for transfers $200 & up.
author: A Mighty Life

text: Yeah, there are a lot of negative comments. But there are also those who say that the app works for them. At the end of the day, we make comparisons and choose what works for ourselves. In my case, Remitly, Xoom, and Transferwise are my top 3. Although, I still compare exchange rates and fees among the three because it can still vary.       For USD (from the US) to a USD account in the Philippines, I have used Xoom.com in the past and had been satisfied although I feel that the fee is still a bit high. I hope you find what works for you.
author: A Mighty Life

text: I worked almost 40 years in a commercial company.  It the beginning, it was over 1500 employees. Towards the end it shrank to less than 150.  Due to politics in the company, I was miserable going to work every day.  Real estate market was high, mortgage paid, and I always had a desire to retire out of the country.  While on a 6 week vacation in the Philippines, we found a great house and put a deposit,  once you retire, your SS benefits will never increase because you are no longer contributing to SS.  Therefore, in this case, collect immediately.  My SS is deposited in my US bank and set up before retiring, i can transfer dollars to a dollar account in the Philippines.

With my age now, I can feel that I won't last staying here for good considering that we still have some properties in the Phil. Would you pls enlighten me how long do I need to stay here to avail of SS benefits/pension. I am also eager to have US citizenship, If I can wait so I can easily visit my children living abroad. I want to know also other benefits accorded a US   citizen. Thank you very much, Sir, and more power!
author: Danilo Flores

text: Just one other thing.. if waiting till age 70 to collect instead of 66- 67 you collect 28%-32% more than at full retirement age. Than means $1,280- $1,320 instead of the $730 and then $1,000 or whatever it was at 62 and 66 years old.   Anyway, same guy waits till 70 yrs old and collects $1,320 till age 90 will get $316,800 over 20 years. He gets just over $236,000 over 28 years collecting at 62 to age 90.. Enjoyed all this figuring you did üëãüëçAlso if you saved the SS and put into "I"...... bonds, then you protect those years of savings with rate of inflation returns.. Up to $10k a year you can purchase per person per year.

author: Gedelyn Banaag

text: I‚Äôve been your regular viewer for quite sometime. However, it never crossed my mind to ask for advise  from you regarding an inquiry about my pension benefit. I worked for about 11 years when I decided to apply for SS retirement benefit in 2016 at the age of 66. That time,  i had an idea of more or less how much i will receive since the estimated amount is shown in the online SS account where I‚Äôm signed up. This is relevant to me since It wasn‚Äôt  a big amount tho‚Äô but to me it was good enough inasmuch as my income when i worked in the US was not that much. I was asked during the interview if I was receiving any pension in the Phils. which to all honesty I answered yes. I was surprised that when i received my final check i got a very small amount since the equivalent of the pension I was getting in the Phils. was deducted . I tried to call them but they said that was how it should be. The next time i attempted they asked about a record or statement of how much i was receiving which I did not have as I haven‚Äôt been home for years.  At that  time, I wasn‚Äôt a citizen yet.  At present, because of the pandemic there is no way to talk to them personally and they‚Äôre reply over the phone is still the same. I‚Äôm not quite convinced as yet why a benefit you got from another country long before you came here  will be deducted from the benefit you deserve to receive . I don‚Äôt understand the reason that it was covered by a ‚Äúwindfall‚Äù something they were explaining. In my simple thinking as an ordinary  citizen, I couldn‚Äôt understand  why a hard earned money I deserve to receive for working more  than 10 years will be affected by another benefit you are received from your home counrty. It was not even an ‚ÄúSSI‚Äù that you get for free. Pls. help  enlighten me. Thank you so much for all the help you‚Äôre doing for all your viewers. I‚Äôm sure others may have the same concern, too.

text: How much you pay the IRS depends on your TOTAL income.  The more income you have, the higher your tax rate.  Therefore, if you start collecting SS while you are still working, your total income will be higher.  What's the result?  Higher taxes.
author: Vlogger Grandpa, USA

text: Just remember that the projected SS benefit at FRA, on the statements from that you get from SSA, assumes that your latest annual income will continue until you reach FRA.  SSA assumes that it will get the same amount of FICA tax from both employee and employer. If you start working less hours to stay below the SSA earnings limit, this will result in a lower amount of FICA tax. Consequently, this will reduce the benefit that you will receive at FRA, since the benefit is based on the last 35 years of FICA taxes paid.  Also remember that the spousal benefit is usually 50% of the primary beneficiary‚Äôs pension if the claim is made at FRA.  If the spousal benefit is claimed earlier than FRA, the percentage is reduced by a formula from the SSA and could be as low as 32%, instead of the 50%.

text: The earliest a widow or widower can start receiving Social Security survivors benefits based on age will remain at age 60. Widows or widowers benefits based on age can start any time between age 60 and full retirement age as a survivor. If the benefits start at an earlier age, they are reduced a fraction of a percent for each month before full retirement age.  If a person receives widow's or widower's benefits, and will qualify for a retirement benefit that's more than their survivors benefit, they can switch to their own retirement benefit as early as age 62 or as late as age 70. The rules are complicated and vary depending on the situation. Talk to a Social Security representative about the options available.

text: I like the video; it's well done. However, determining when to begin receiving SSI isn't quite so simple.  While the numbers in themselves make sense, there are complications to be borne in mind.  The median average life expectancy of 62 year old men is about 25 years and 28 years for women.  What this means is that (using the 3% historic annual inflation discount), unless you have a significant illness or a family history of much shorter than average life spans, the smart move is to wait as long as you can.  Why? because every year you live beyond the break even point of 81 or 82, you will have made more money, altogether, by delaying your SSI claim.  Of course, if you have no other source of income, you'll have to begin collecting earlier than you'd like just to survive.  Another point to consider is that in most years your social security payments will be increased by a % that offsets inflation.  So, the longer you wait to collect SSI, the greater number of dollars each percentage point represents.  The analysis stops at full retirement age.  In my case, 66 years.  for each year you wait, beyond full retirement age, to begin your payments, you get an additional 8% until age 70.  So, for me (using his $$) this would be $1,320 per month at 70 rather than $1,000 at full retirement age, or $733 at 62.  If you're reasonably healthy and you have other income, it really is smart to wait til 70.  Finally, the penalty for working and collecting SSI ($2 for $1 I believe) ends at full retirement age (66).  There is no such penalty for W2 income earned after that age.   Just my $.02.

text: The earliest that you can file is when you are 61 years and 9 months old. https://www.ssa.gov/planners/retire/applying3.html Since you will turn 62 in Jan 2020, you can start the filing process in Nov 2019. There are some weird SSA rules on when you will receive your first payment.  SSA only pays after a whole month.  Unless you were born on Jan 1, your first whole month would be Feb 2020 and you will receive your first payment in March 2020.  Despite the SSA pronouncement that you can start receiving benefits when you turn 62, you actually only start to receive the money when you are 62 years and 2 months old.

text: Some kababayans may not be aware that they might also be entitled to social security benefit from the PHL SSS.  If you worked and contributed for at least 10 years (120 monthly contributions) before immigrating abroad, you can claim your benefit at age 60.  You do not have to be a dual citizen to file the claim.  If you are 60+ and have not yet filed a claim, you will receive an initial lump sum equivalent to 13 months benefit per year that you missed, plus accumulated interest.  If you have less than 120 contributions (for example, you only worked for 8 years in PHL before immigrating abroad) and you are less than 65 years old, you can still pay additional contributions to make up and be eligible.  More information can be found here:  https://www.sss.gov.ph/sss/appmanager/pages.jsp?page=retirementqualifying

text: It took a more than a month to get a response but the SSA International Operations, based in the US Embassy in Manila, formally confirmed that Social Security benefits can be deposited directly into a PHL bank.  The contents of their e-mail is as follows:   Greetings!   Yes you may receive benefits through Direct Deposit in the Philippines by completing a Direct Deposit Sign Up Form. See attached.   Kindly take note that when sending queries to our office, we are unable to access the record and reply to your query without your date of birth and the last 4 digits of  your SSN. Thus, I am basing my reply on the information that you already provided.  Please be also advised that SSA Manila handles the East Asia Pacific Region. Due to workload volume, queries are responded to in the order that they were received. For faster service or for urgent matters, please do not hesitate to call our inquiry line at +63-2-301-2000 extension 9 between 8 am to 11 am Manila time, Tuesdays and Thursdays. Several phone representatives are available to assist you. You may also leave your message and request for a call back through the voice mail system.   For SSA related matters and Most Asked Questions, we invite you to visit our website at www.ssa.gov.  Rest assured that SSA is here to  take care of your concerns.  Thank you.   Arleh Lara SSA International Operations Embassy of the United States of America 1201 Roxas Blvd., 0930 Manila Philippines  New Operating Hours effective December 3, 2018:   In-Office Appointments and Walk-In Services: 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, except Philippine and U.S. Holidays Telephone Hours: 8:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m. (Manila Time), Tuesdays and Thursdays, except Philippine and U.S. Holidays Phone Number: + 63-2 301 2000 extension 9

text: The two-month delay in receiving your first SS payment is another example of weird SSA rules.  Social Security does not make partial-month payments. Unless you were born on May 1st, your first full month of eligibility is June.  Since the Social Security Administration pays individuals a month behind, the person will receive the June benefit in July. The check will arrive on the 2nd, 3rd, or 4th Wednesday, depending on your day of birth.  For example, if you were born on May 10th you will get your first payment on July 10 but if you were born one day later, May 11, you have to wait until July 17.  The shortest waiting time is for a person born on May 1 (42 days) but, the worst-case scenario is the person born the following day on May 2, who has to wait 69 days before receiving his first SS payment.  So the person born on May 1 will receive his first payment almost one whole month earlier than the person born on May 2!  So, while at first glance you might think you can get your benefits when you turn 62, the first payment does not happen until you are 62 years and 2  months old...

text: At the age of 65, you will automatically qualified for Medicare Part A (because you already paid that while you were working-- payroll deduction and this will pay for your hospitalization).¬† It is up to you if you want to enroll in Medicare Part B and the monthly¬†premium now is around $129.00 ( this will pay for your lab & x-ray, office visits).¬† You're $1586.00 is a little high for you to be qualified for MEDICAID (FREE MEDICAL COVERAGE FROM THE STATE).¬†¬† UNFORTUNATELY, MEDICARE WILL NOT PAY FOR OUT OF COUNTRY HOSPITALIZATION OR TREATMENT.¬† I HAD TO WRITE THE SS OFFICE¬† WITH MY AUNT'S CONSENT TO CANCEL¬†HER COVERAGE BECUASE SHE DECIDED TO STAY IN THE PHILIPPINES FOR GOOD.¬† By the way one of my condo is also in Taguig (GRACE SMDC).¬† You can actually see the MARKET MARKET sign from the balcony.¬†¬† I'm glad you're enjoying your retirement.¬† I also stop working last December 2018.¬† I started working here in the US before I turn 16 yrs old.¬† I also worked 35 years including part time jobs when I was in high school and college.¬† Now, i'm just managing my Adult Family Home and it's nice because less stress.¬† I have really nice and reliable caregivers and it makes a lot of difference.

text: Well, the numbers don't lie but we can learn the wrong lessons by not thinking the numbers through.  While you might die before the breakeven age of 82, changes are really good, unless you're suffering from a significant illness at 62, you'll probably live.  The government knows all this too.  They look at the averages and know they'll pay you less (on average) if you take your retirement early--that's why they offer this in the first place.  Since most people begin taking SSI from 62-66, the government wins.

I had seen at least 3 who have retired after working for at least 30 yrs, same work place only to die suddenly dahil nadiagnose ng cancer stage 4, na stroke, and yung isa nakalimutan ko na po (i think cancer din yun sya). it became a wake up call sa iba naming employees who were trying to delay their retirement dahil nga gusto nila makuha full benefits nila. right now, most of them are saying they didn't regret retiring and they are happier with their life.

text: ¬†@Vlogger Grandpa, USA¬† True.  But the adjustments are a pittance compared to the FICA deduction.  My wife tried to play that game of earning less than the $1/$2 penalty limit and all she got was a $9 adjustment to her monthly benefit.  It will take more than 12 years to recover that FICA deduction. And while there is an age limit of 66 for $1/$2 penalty, there is no age limit on FICA deductions.  So, you could be a 90-year old YT Vlogger and still pay the 15.3% FICA on your earnings. Some of these SSA rules are absolutely ridiculous!
author: mvescuadra

text: ¬†@mvescuadra¬† True.  However, your benefit will be adjusted and you will receive a lumpsum adjustment in addition to increasing your future monthly benefit because of the additional earnings you have.
author: Vlogger Grandpa, USA

text: ¬†@Vlogger Grandpa, USA¬† Even if you earned exactly $17,640 to avoid the $1/$2 penalty, you are still giving back some of the money in terms of FICA tax.  At the current FICA rate of 7.65%, you are giving back $1350 out of the $17,640 to the SSA.  If you are free-lancing or self-employed during retirement, the rate is 15.3% or $2700 back to the SSA even if you earned exactly $17,640.
author: mvescuadra

text: Tax is something that is completely separate.  The problem is that the benefit you should be getting may be reduced or completely eliminated depending on your income from work.  As far as tax goes, SS benefit is always taxable unless your "total income including SS benefit" do not exceed your total standard deduction.

author: Vlogger Grandpa, USA

text: ¬†@Vlogger Grandpa, USA¬† There is a small gotcha in this situation.  SSA‚Äôs calculation of your benefit is made on the assumption that you will continue to earn at least the same amount as your last reported annual salary and consequently the same FICA deductions.  If you stop working at age 55, use your ‚Äòother source‚Äô and collect at 62, you will have 7 years of zero salary and zero FICA deductions in the SSA records.  This will result in a smaller benefit than what is currently projected in your SSA records.

author: Magikerong Sugarol

text: Like  he said, it depends on where you will retire and the lifestyle you have. If you decide to live in Manila, I think you're main concern will be housing. The price for the condo unit back in 2012 has tremendously increased. But between $400-700 monthly rent will be a very nice house/apartment . Less if you choose a smaller one and of course it also depends where in Manila. Other places are far more expensive than others. I think food wise, you 'll be okay with $200/month if you plan on cooking at home. Eating out will be different of course. Not sure if you can use your benefit for housing loan in the Philippines if you decide to acquire a property. People who served has a very good discount or rate for housing loans. Not sure if you are aware of it. We have a VA ofc that you can go to in Pasay, which is in Manila ( I'm not mistaken, it is near the US embassy) and they have providers that can see you. With the New Mission Act, you can be referred to a non-VA provider if they can not address your health concern. If you have not established yourself as a pt within VA, now is the time to get to it so that you'll be in the system and hopefully, it will be much easier for you to transition there. And so, if you decide to live in the province and you'll encounter any health issues, you can see a provider locally and doesn't have to travel Manila to go to the VA ofc and they can simply make the consult/referral for you. At least, this is how I understand it. Better to ask the VA still. Hope that helps.

text: It really depends on where exactly you're going to go, and the kind of lifestyle you're going to have.  I suggest that you do what I did.  That is, when you go on vacation spend more time looking at rentals so you know how much they are in the area you are interested in, estimate your food expenses, and other expenses you can inquire about.  Then put together a budget and you will know if you will be able to survive in that location.  Also, make sure you get updated information as to how much Social Security check you will get when you retire.  The number you quoted may only be an estimate, and I don't want you to be blindsided.  Generally, you will be able to survive with that kind of income from Social Security.  Avoid Manila, because it's very expensive there.  Hopefully this helps.

text: It depends on your situation.  Do you need extra income that you have to work?  Will that work exceed the limit, such that your social security payout will be reduced? text: TransferWise is definitely a great tool to send money easily specially within European accounts as the fees are low and seems to be transparent in that way.      However, no body says anything about the transfers in USD to a USD account outside the US.   TransferWise would charge a fee of about USD4.60 to transfer your USD funds from the borderless account to a USD account outside of the US, mentioning the transfer has to be done via SWIFT.    They have a link if you navigate thoroughly on their website, where they say you can be charged up to USD50 on top as SWIFT transfers  may involve transferring the money through multiple banks.   I personally had a horrible experience being charged USD70 for a transfer from my USD Borderless account to USD account outside of the US.      On the section where you are intending to place the transfer, does not give a warning that you may be charged a huge amount of money, they just say "additional fees may apply when transferring via SWIFT".      Bear in mind these details, I understand people want to promote TransferWise online to get some free cash by using their link to encourage people to use it, which is great, however, whoever is intending to transfer USD to a non US bank account, you might get an awful surprise! TransferWise customer service will not make any effort to help you at all but just talk to you as you were a retarded repeating what you already know, you've been ripped off but they do not take responsibilities how much you will end up getting once the money leaves their bank account.

text: Presenting your old Philippine Passport is optional.  If you do not have it, you don't need to present it to apply for dual citizenship.  Many people destroys their old Philippine passport after they get their U.S. citizenship.  Your Philippine birth certificate will be the important document to present to prove being a former Filipino citizen.

text: Your daughter, I assume, is an American citizen because she was born in the U.S.  Is that correct?  If yes, she is also a Filipino citizen because both parents are Filipino citizens at the time of her birth, regardless of where she was born.  All you have to do is to file a delayed Report of Birth at the Philippine Consulate.  Once approved, she can also apply for a Philippine Passport.  She will then have dual passports, Philippine and U.S.  There is no need to file for Dual Citizenship .

author: David Hutton

text: Of the 4 major US banks, only Citibank has retail banking operations in PH.  BofA, WF, and Chase have a presence in PH, but they only cater to commercial/merchant clients.  Citi only has 3 branches and 3 ATM centers in PH.  I tried Citi in PH about 10 years ago, but due to the horrendous traffic conditions in Metro Manila, it took me almost an hour to get to the nearest branch in Eastwood, which was only 3 miles away. I just decided to do my banking with a BPI branch which was 10 minutes away from our house.  It could be OK if you live very close to one of the Citi branches; otherwise, look for other options.

text: The WF Portfolio program mentioned at 15:32 has two tiers: Portfolio and Portfolio Plus (WFP+).  The $4 ExpressSend fee is only waived for the WFP+, and not for the regular Portfolio.  An overall relationship (checking, savings, brokerage, retirement funds etc.) of at least $250K is required to qualify for WFP+. In Danny‚Äôs example, the difference between Wise and WFP+ would have been reduced to only PHP122, since the $4 fee is waived.  But another advantage of WFP+ is international ATM fees are waived.  It is like the Schwab ATM except WFP+ waives the ATM fees on the same day of the withdrawal, instead of end of the month for Schwab. Since the ATM withdrawal in PH is based on the local bank‚Äôs exchange rate (not WF exchange rate), it is like exchanging your dollar bills at the bank, which is the best exchange rate you could get, as mentioned by Danny, but without carrying actual dollar bills.  You only carry one ATM card, whether you are in the US or somewhere else in the world.  We moved some of our IRA‚Äôs from Fidelity to WF to qualify for WFP+.  Since it is a self-managed IRA, the fees and yields would have been the same, anyway, whether it is parked in Fidelity or WF.

text: Hey Grandpa, let me add a few cents here. I have already done this, knowing my wife and I will be retiring in the Philippines soon. I opened a Charles Schwab account. Do this BEFORE leaving the USA.  Link your bank account and CS account. You will receive a debit card from CS.  You can transfer funds from your bank to SC, no fee's. Now while in the Philippines , you can use any ATM to get your funds, but their will be fee's at each ATM.            At the end of the month, CS will refund, to your account, ALL atm fee's. Also, when sending money to yourself while living in Philippines, always send yourself DOLLARS, (If your from USA) Then you can go to any bank in the Philippines and get the true exchange rate for that day.

text: I have a passbook Account(savings) with an ATM account with the same bank here. I have a portion of my monthly U.S. pension direct deposited into my Philippine bank. I can bill pay and xfer money with my Philippine account. It has many of the same features as the major U.S. banks. My overall experience is Filipino banks are NOT truly foreign friendly as there is much more hoops to jump through just to open an account here. Also, be sure who you're dealing with inside your bank here. There are many options and services you can utilize from your bank here but many of the employees (including bank officers) lack knowledge of these things. You usually find out after the fact and it can be a letdown. And this is why most banks here are not foreigner friendly. Just something one has to adjust to. Nice informational vlog! Ingat.

text: I was shocked to find out that often, electronics can cost a LOT more in the Philippines.  A new phone or Laptop ... You would think it is the opposite....  that it would be a LOWER cost~ but it's not.  And costs even MORE to ship something to Ph., than you might think, I was shocked....   I did (of course) educate myself in typical wages earned, the cost of milk, food, utilities, pharma & travel costs... etc ...  and yes, I do have experience paying for Phone (data costs $$$ for a Filipina girl)  Xoom is a good & helpful app for that  ...if you spend a lot of time on phone with her, texting or sharing photos etc, it may be typical for a guy to pay for her phone / data too.... as a gentleman might.  You are correct in pointing out that often, men obligate themselves  ...so, once you step over THAT particular threshold within your own mind (emotionally) ... try to be certain it is what you want to do.  IF you do CARE about the Girl, do not forget, she may come to depend upon what you give her.  Then...?  IF giving the money becomes a point of contention? You can mess up your "Good" relationship with your LDR-Filipina  ... what I mean is this.  if you obligate yourself & get into a "Habit" with her..... (and she is entirely comfortable with you & the "giving" situation) do not then TURN AROUND and FREAK OUT ON HER! .... if you (the guy doing the giving) has a problem with the Peso's you supply her....  and if you begin to feel she doesn't appreciate it.  That may not be the case at all  You might INDEED have "achieved" ... making her feel Loved & SECURE......  ... and she is not being ungrateful ... but she Merely, COMPLETELY TOTALLY BELIEVES IN YOU.... And... she believes in your LDR with her, & that you CARE  .... (if she is a good girl)(and often they ARE "good girls")  it is very easy to grow unhappy, with Your Own ROLE as "The Giver" ................ Do Not Blame The Girl ....  often, these ARE "Good Girls" and yes, there are also girls who know how to:  "Work The Men for $$$"  .... they are not all criminals Often, you CAN tell, when a girl is from a province, and directly involved with her family.... and if she pretty much shares all of her life at ANY TIME of the day with you.... after a while?  Yes, you can probably allow yourself to trust her.  I got lucky.  Found a "GOOD" Girl..... she was indeed a Good Girl and a Good Human being I am writing this because even THEN.... it is not EASY to maintain your own mental / emotional stability in a LDR it is demanding sometimes, and can definitely TEST you.  The info you are getting in these video's is quite quite Excellent..... he knows what he's talking about .........

text: There are many good reasons NOT to send money. And you've appropriately expounded on all of them. I am in agreement with you wholeheartedly. I am planning to visit the Philippines when the country opens. My Dad encouraged me to do that for many years prior to his passing. He was a pilot and stationed there in WWII. I also happen to be single (widower) and I would be open to developing a relationship. But I would certainly not do so out of desperation, as some men appear to do. But my comment is that perhaps the offer is made to see what type of reaction is generated. If there's been no previous talk of money, there's likely no immediate need for it either. And if, for example, she's hesitant or has declined the offer, then perhaps she's genuine and sincere, as you so often say that most Filipinas are. I apologize for the digression, but the comment may or may not have some merit. You are much wiser on the subject matter than me.

author: Robert Wheeler

text: Send as much money as you can so she and her family can live okay. Most Filipinos can't even afford a refrigerator, washing machine or television, let alone a house, so even if you send her twenty thousand pesos, she still might not live as well as you considering she might have family including her parents to help support. Fresh food  is not cheap in the Philippines like even rice is around 40 pesos a kilo and a lot of fruit and vegetables are also around that price. I have seen apples at 40 pesos each apple and potatoes at 120 pesos per kilo, so the prices are similar to Australia. Actually appliances like refrigerators and washing machines seem to be more expensive than Australia. You can find out all this information from watching other Expats YouTube videos. Oh, if the relationship doesn't work out, just think of all the help you have given as charity knowing that you have helped Filipinos out of poverty at least for a while. ‚ò∫

text: Eric, The amount one may send to a Filipina really depends on the amount of money you have and what her circumstance is. For example if I work a minimum wage job then finding $100 a month may be hard, but if I am a CEO of a company then I could easily give $500 a month and it wouldn't be missed. The main point here is don't take away from a Filipinas pride in herself to be independent and proud to be able to look after herself. Don't make her feel like a kept woman. If she has no job or a job that only pays a little then help accordingly within your budget so you don't end up broke yourself. As I say in the video 2500 - 4000 pesos will provide the bare necessities for her to get by and again you don't want to be fully subsidising her life.

text: MORE OFTEN THAN NOT.... your Filipina Girl will always be understanding  IF it comes to where you do have a problem giving her money... just be honest with her. Tell her that ...YOU... are undergoing $ stresses.   (The bias is a tendency to think that Americans / Westerners are "Rich".... and you are not "rich") (yet many Philippines people EASILY will blurt out, "you're American, you're RICH") ( ... educate them gently)   She will not understand the stresses that YOU live with     So.... if giving her money is a problem... Try to not let your ego be in the way of being OPEN & gentle with her about it.  Explain the "problem" or difficulty you are having, & do your best to remain patient... ALWAYS.  .................................... and then withdraw the funding or reduce it drastically... as you need  Remember TRY NOT TO LET ...your ego... DO THE TALKING IN YOUR HEAD do not feel "Guilty"   Be .......................... calm.  (even if she gets upset) ... this can be a GOOD "test" of your relationship. And it will also definitely TEST your own character.  IF... she is a "Good Girl" ... often SHE will actually begin to feel guilty, or like you are punishing her, if you withdraw funding............   She will DEFINITELY "wonder" what SHE DID to cause you to withdraw financial support.... so this can be prickly in many ways.   ...and if she actually DOES CARE about you?  ... she will not withdraw her "Care" ... for YOU She may suddenly begin talking a LOT lot more about how she can go out and make money now.   Remember, ... your OWN ego, may figure into how you react to ANY statements from her !  And this?  will more likely make YOU feel guilty that she is doing it.  Listening to her talk about working or trying to compensate for losing your $ support ................  It may play with your head, and make you ANGRY (because now YOU feel guilty) and you may with your Western thinking style .... begin to think that SHE is toying with you or saying it unaware that she is making YOU uncomfortable .....................she probably ~ is ~ making you uncomfortable if she says this. (and she is unaware of it) Keep a Grip on yourself  Long Distance Relationships  (LDR's) are not easy......  do not psyche YOURSELF OUT   and then undermine your own relationship with your own anger / insecure thoughts

text: @Kelly Taber    I agree with what Dave has said, you don't have anything to worry about and you will be sure to have a great experience. author: All About Filipina Relationships

text: if you want to stay in Ormoc overnite, I can recommend a nice place I stayed at near the Saban resort.
author: Dave Trotter

text: I have been to Tacloban in Jan of this year, and you don't have much to worry about.  I would land in Cebu, and take the fast ferry to Ormoc, then a van to Tacloban. you can easily find the van at the terminal, you can walk there from the ferry terminal, just turn left out of the gate, and walk towards the market.  I ended up going from Massin, by van, and it was okay, but the road is twisty and turny, and they stop half way there.  had to go and renew my visa.  it was a nice day trip since I had never been. take it from me, it's a piece of cake, if you need more info, just ask.
author: Dave Trotter

text: @Harb Doad  Thank you, glad you enjoy my videos and find good value in them. For sure, one needs to weigh the relationship up and also their own finances and decide what is reasonable. The Philippines is such an amazing Country and the people so friendly. You will enjoy that experience for sure when the time comes! Take care.

text: My dad sent her money. I guess that when he ask her for her acct she did not hesitate and gv her not her own acct number but her so called sister's acct number. text: Certainly your Dad sounds like he was a wise man as the Philippines is an amazing Country. If one is looking for a loving relationship he can find it as can guys find a relationship based on things other then love. As I always say, A genuine Filipina is also a proud and independent woman so she certainly wont be asking or hinting for money. I remember in the early stages of my relationship I offered my Now wife a few hundred dollars to see what she if she was genuine and of course she rejected the offer telling me she was fine and has a job. I knew right then and there she was a good and genuine woman. Your comment is certainly welcome and has merit for sure.
